{{gbmappingsmall|TQ227720}} | [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web | url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/protectedsites/sacselection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0030301 | title=Wimbledon Common | publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee | accessdate=16 January 2016}} | align="center" |{{Nature on the map|1004317}} | [https://web.archive.org/web/20121024053604/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004317.pdf Citation] |The common has an extensive area of wet acidic heathland, and other areas of dense semi-natural woodland on clay. There are many streams and plants uncommon in the London area. Other features are [[bog moss]]es and locally important breeding birds.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004317.pdf |title=Wimbledon Common citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=31 May 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024053604/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004317.pdf |archivedate=24 October 2012 |df= }} |} {{commons category|Sites of Special Scientific Interest in London}} ==See also== *[[List of Local Nature Reserves in Greater London]] *[[London Wildlife Trust]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{SSSI AOS lists}} {{SSSIs Greater London}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Sites of Special Scientific Interest in London| ]] [[Category:Lists of Sites of Special Scientific Interest by Area of Search|London]] [[Category:London nature-related lists|SSSI]]

This '''list of West Africa hurricanes''' includes all [[tropical cyclone]]s which originated in the [[Atlantic]] and directly or indirectly affected the west coast of Africa or its surrounding islands, or both. Atlantic hurricanes seldom directly affect [[West Africa]], the [[Cape Verde Islands]], or the [[Canary Islands]], since easterly winds carry the storms away from land, and most Atlantic storms that move off the African coast tend to be weak. [[Image:Ts delta 112405.jpg|right|thumb|Tropical Storm Delta before hitting the [[Canary Islands]] on November 28, 2005]] ==List of tropical cyclones== This is a list of tropical cyclones that have either made direct landfall in Western Africa and its surrounding islands or have come close to making landfall. ===Before 1950=== * September 10, 1900: A tropical storm formed on September 8, 1900, at 10°N-18.5°W and moved northwestward. The storm rapidly gained strength as it reached hurricane on September 9. The hurricane continued moving northwestward as it bypassed the [[Cape Verde Islands]] to the west at [[Saffir–Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 1]] strength. The storm later reached Category 2 status after passing the islands. Despite its close proximity to the islands, it's unclear if any watches or warnings were issued nor were any reports of damage or fatalities reported from the storm.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2007|title=Weather Underground 1900 Archive|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at190003.asp}} * August 29, 1901: A tropical depression formed on August 29 and moved westward where it became a tropical storm. The storm brushed the Cape Verde's before continuing on westward and becoming a hurricane. The storm caused no damage on the islands.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2007|title=Weather Underground 1901 Archive|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at190106.asp}} * August 25, 1906: A tropical storm brushed the [[Cape Verde Islands]] as a 40 mph (64 km/h) tropical storm causing no damage. Days later, the storm strengthened into a [[Saffir–Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 4]] hurricane.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2007|title=Weather Underground 1906 Archive|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at190604.asp}} * September 2, 1927 : A weak tropical storm passed through the [[Cape Verde Islands]] before becoming a category 2 hurricane. There was no recorded damage after the storm's passing through the islands.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2007|title=Weather Underground 1927 Archive|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at192702.asp}} * September 6, 1928: The '''[[1928 Lake Okeechobee Hurricane]]''' passed through the Cape Verde Islands as a weak tropical storm.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2007|title=Weather Underground 1928 Archive|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at192804.asp}} * September 10, 1938: Before becoming a hurricane, the '''[[1938 New England Hurricane]]''' passed through the Cape Verde Islands as a 40 mph (64 km/h) [[tropical storm]].{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2007|title=Weather Underground 1938 Archive|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at193804.asp}} * September 5, 1947: The '''[[1947 Fort Lauderdale Hurricane|Fort Lauderdale Hurricane]]''' brushed the [[Cape Verde Islands]] as a Category 1 hurricane at 0000 UTC. There were no reports of damage or injuries from the hurricane.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2007|title=Weather Underground 1947 Archive|accessdate=2007-01-10|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at194704.asp}} * September 5, 1948: A mid season hurricane brushed the [[Cape Verde Islands]] as a [[Saffir–Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 1]] storm. There were no reports of damage or injuries from that storm.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1948 Archive|accessdate=2006-08-15|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at194806.asp}} ===1950-1979=== * August 19, 1952: '''[[Hurricane Able (1952)|Tropical Depression Two]]''' struck the Cape Verde Islands before becoming a hurricane.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1952 Archive|accessdate=2006-08-02|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at195202.asp}} * August 28, 1953: '''[[Hurricane Carol (1953)|Tropical Depression Four]]''' passed through the Cape Verde Islands before becoming a hurricane.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1953 Archive|accessdate=2006-08-02|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at195304.asp}} * September 3, 1957: While transitioning to a tropical storm, '''[[Hurricane Carrie|Tropical Depression Four]]''' passed south of the [[Cape Verde Islands]] causing no damage.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1957 Archive|accessdate=2006-08-02|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at195704.asp}} * August 8, 1958: '''[[1958 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Becky|Tropical Depression Two]]''' passed through the [[Cape Verde Islands]] before reaching tropical storm strength. There were no reports of damage.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1958 Archive|accessdate=2006-08-02|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at195802.asp}} * September 5, 1964: '''[[1964 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Florence|Tropical Depression Eight]]''' brushed the Cape Verde Islands before reaching tropical storm strength. The storm caused no known damage.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1964 Archive|accessdate=2006-08-02|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at196408.asp}} * September 5, 1967: '''[[1967 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Chloe|Tropical Depression Three]]''' passed through the Cape Verde Islands before becoming a hurricane.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1967 Archive|accessdate=2006-07-21|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at196703.asp}} * October 5, 1967: '''[[1967 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Ginger|Tropical Storm Ginger]]''' formed east of the Cape Verde Islands on October 5. The storm reached a peak intensity of 50 mph before dissipating two days later. Ginger's formation was the farthest east on record for an Atlantic [[tropical cyclone]].{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1967 Archive|accessdate=2006-07-24|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at196707.asp}}{{cite web|author=Arnold L. Sugg and Joseph M. Pelmisser|year=1968|title=Hurricane Season of 1967|publisher=''[[NOAA]]''|accessdate=2006-07-24|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1967.pdf}} * September 12, 1968: '''[[1968 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Edna|Tropical Depression Seven]]''' brushed the Cape Verde Islands before reaching tropical storm strength.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1968 Archive|accessdate=2006-07-21|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at196805.asp}} * August 25, 1973: '''[[Tropical Storm Christine (1973)|Tropical Depression Nine]]''' formed over western Africa at 10°N-15°W before reaching tropical storm strength.{{cite web|author=Hurricane.com|year=2007|title=Tropical Storm Christine (1973) best track data|accessdate=2007-05-08|url=http://www.hurricane.com/hurricane-season/hurricane-CHRISTINE-1973-983.php}} * September 15, 1973: '''[[1973 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Ellen|Tropical Storm Ellen]]''' brushed the Cape Verde Islands as a 45 mph (72 km/h) tropical storm,{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1973 Archive|accessdate=2006-07-21|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at197306.asp}} before becoming a hurricane. * September 4, 1979: '''[[1979 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Gloria|Tropical Depression Eleven]]''' brushed the northern Cape Verde Islands before becoming a hurricane.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1979 Archive|accessdate=2006-07-20|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at197907.asp}} ===1980-1999=== [[Image:Tropical Storm Beryl - Atlantic.JPG|right|thumb|Tropical Storm Beryl]] * September 4, 1980: '''[[1980 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Earl|Tropical Depression Nine]]''' brushed the northern Cape Verde Islands hours before becoming a hurricane.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1980 Archive|accessdate=2006-07-21|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at198005.asp}} * August 29, 1982: '''[[Tropical Storm Beryl (1982)|Tropical Storm Beryl]]''' of 1982 passed south of the [[Cape Verde Islands]], killing 3 people and injuring 112 people.{{cite web|author=Gilbert C. Clark |year=1983 |title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1982 |publisher=NOAA |accessdate=2006-07-17 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1982.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111210225106/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1982.pdf |archivedate=2011-12-10 |df= }}{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center|year=2005|title=The Deadliest Atlantic Tropical Cyclones, 1492-1996|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2006-07-17|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pastdeadlyapp1.shtml?}} * September 16, 1984: '''[[Tropical Storm Fran (1984)|Tropical Depression Nine]]''' bypassed the [[Cape Verde Islands]] to the south before reaching [[tropical storm]] strength.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1984 Archive|accessdate=2006-07-17|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at198407.asp}} The storm killed 31 people, mainly from landslides and flooding. * September 8, 1988: '''[[1988 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Thirteen|Tropical Storm Thirteen]]''' formed extremely close to western [[Africa]] on September 6 where it moved slightly northwestward and dissipated. It was not named because of its extreme location at the time, and it was originally thought to be a tropical depression. However, post storm analysis revealed that the system had maintained tropical storm strength for at least 48 hours. The storm produced heavy rain but caused no reported damage. * September 18, 1989: Before reaching hurricane status, '''[[1989 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Erin|Hurricane Erin]]''' passed through the Cape Verde Islands as a [[tropical depression]], causing no damage.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1989 Archive|accessdate=2006-07-17|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at198905.asp}} * September 21, 1998: '''[[Hurricane Jeanne (1998)|Hurricane Jeanne]]''' of 1998 passed south of the [[Cape Verde Islands]] as a Category 1 hurricane.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 1998 Archive|accessdate=2006-07-17|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at199810.}} Because of Jeanne's rapid formation, forecasters predicted that the storm will bring tropical storm conditions to the [[Cape Verde Islands]]. However, the storm's center stayed off shore and there were no reports of damage.{{cite web|author=Mayfield|year=1998|title=Tropical Storm Jeanne Advisory #2|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2006-07-17|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/pub/PAL1098.002}} ===2000-present=== [[File:Fred 2015-08-31 1215Z.jpg|upright=.8|thumb|Hurricane Fred at Category 1 strength over Cape Verde on August 31, 2015.]] * August 4, 2000: The tropical wave that later became '''[[Hurricane Alberto (2000)|Hurricane Alberto]]''' dropped {{convert|1|in}} of rain across [[Dakar, Senegal]] and produced winds of {{convert|40|mph|abbr=on}} off the West African coastline.{{cite web|author=Gary Paddget|year=2000|title=Monthly Global Tropical Summary for June|publisher=Australian Severe Weather|accessdate=2007-11-27|url=http://www.australiansevereweather.com/cyclones/2001/summ0008.htm}} * September 9, 2003: '''[[List of storms in the 2003 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Depression Fourteen|Tropical Depression Fourteen]]''' brushed the [[Cape Verde Islands]] after reaching peak intensity of {{convert|35|mph|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|author=Weather Underground|year=2006|title=Weather Underground 2003 Archive|accessdate=2006-07-17|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/at2003.asp}} The depression produced heavy rainfall and gusty winds to the islands.{{cite web|author=Alvia|year=2003|title=Tropical Depression Fourteen Discussion #8|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-11-26|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2003/dis/al142003.discus.008.shtml?}} * November 23, 2005: '''[[Tropical Storm Delta (2005)|Tropical Storm Delta]]''', after meandering eastward in the [[Atlantic Ocean]] for several days, struck the [[Canary Islands]] shortly after becoming extratropical, and {{convert|70|mph|abbr=on}} winds with 90 mph (150 km/h) gusts caused over $360 million (2005 [[USD]]) in damage and nineteen deaths.{{cite web|author=Staff Writer |year=2005 |title=Delta force in the Canaries |publisher=''Tenerife News'' |accessdate=2006-07-17 |url=http://www.tenerifenews.com/cms/front_content.php?client=1&lang=1&idcat=47&idart=2983 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928021041/http://www.tenerifenews.com/cms/front_content.php?client=1&lang=1&idcat=47&idart=2983 |archivedate=September 28, 2007 }}{{cite web|author=Staff Writer |year=2005 |title=Delta: Aftermath and Impact |publisher=''Tenerife News'' |accessdate=2006-07-17 |url=http://www.tenerifenews.com/cms/front_content.php?client=1&lang=1&idcat=47&idart=3091 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928021033/http://www.tenerifenews.com/cms/front_content.php?client=1&lang=1&idcat=47&idart=3091 |archivedate=September 28, 2007 }} The remnants of Delta then struck [[Morocco]], where no damage was reported. * August 21, 2006: '''[[Tropical Storm Debby (2006)|Tropical Storm Debby]]''' passed south of the [[Cape Verde Islands]] as a tropical depression. A [[tropical cyclone watches and warnings|tropical storm warning]] was issued for the [[Cape Verde Islands]], but was discontinued when Debby turned further westward and away from the islands. * September 9, 2010: '''[[Hurricane Igor|Tropical Storm Igor]]''' passed about {{convert|30|mi}} to the south of the southernmost [[Cape Verde Islands]],{{cite web|author=FORECASTER CANGIALOSI/BRENNAN|year=2010|title=TROPICAL STORM IGOR ADVISORY NUMBER 5|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2010-09-10|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2010/al11/al112010.public.005.shtml?}} bringing tropical storm force winds to [[Brava, Cape Verde|Brava]] & [[Fogo, Cape Verde|Fogo]],{{cite web|author=UNKNOWN|year=2010|title=TROPICAL STORM IGOR CUMULATIVE WIND HISTORY|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2010-09-10|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/refresh/graphics_at1+shtml/083213.shtml?swath#contents}} before reaching hurricane strength. * August 31, 2015: '''[[Hurricane Fred (2015)|Hurricane Fred]]''' reached Category 1 strength as it hit Cape Verde, resulting in hurricane conditions across many of the islands. Seven people died when their fishing boat capsized off the coast of [[Guinea-Bissau]], and another two fishermen were presumed dead after never returning to [[Boa Vista, Cape Verde|Boa Vista]]. * September 8, 2018: '''[[2018 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Helene|Tropical Storm Helene]]''' dropped heavy rainfall in [[Guinea]], triggering flooding that claimed three lives in [[Doko, Guinea|Doko]].{{cite news|language=French|author=Mohamed Moro Sacko|publisher=Guinea News|date=September 6, 2018|accessdate=September 8, 2018|title=Siguiri : Trois morts suite à des pluies duliviennnes à Doko|url=https://www.guineenews.org/siguiri-trois-morts-suite-a-des-pluies-duliviennnes-a-doko/}} ==Monitoring stations== The [[Cape Verde Islands]] has only one tropical cyclone monitoring station in [[Sal, Cape Verde|Sal]].{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center|year=2007|title=NHC database|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-09-26|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/stations/08594.shtml}} In [[Africa|Western Africa]], there are three tropical cyclone monitoring stations in [[Dakar, Senegal]],{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center|year=2007|title=61641 Dakar, Senegal|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-09-26|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/stations/61641.shtml}} [[Bamako, Mali]]{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center|year=2007|title=61291 Bamako, Mali|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-09-26|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/stations/61291.shtml}} and [[Niamey, Niger]]{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center|year=2007|title=61052 Niamey, Niger|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-09-26|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/stations/61052.shtml}} ==Climatological statistics== At least 31 tropical cyclones have affected Western Africa and its surrounding islands since records began in 1851. The majority of the storms affect West Africa and Cape Verde islands during the months of August and September which are the active months of a typical Atlantic hurricane season.{{cite web|author=Chris Landsea|year=2007|title=FAQ Subject: A2) What is a "Cape Verde" hurricane?|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-12-14|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/A2.html}} {{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}}
{| class="wikitable" align="center" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Month ! Number of recorded storms
affecting West Africa |- | August || 10 |- | September || 19 |- | October || 1 |- | November || 1 |} {{Col-2}} DateFormat=yyyy ImageSize= width:350 height:auto barincrement:35 Period = from:0 till:25 TimeAxis = orientation:horizontal PlotArea = right:10 left:5 bottom:50 top:5 Colors= id:cat5red value:rgb(1,0.2,0.2) id:minorline value:rgb(0.9,0.9,0.9) id:line value:rgb(0.5,0.5,0.5) PlotData= width:15 textcolor:black shift:(5,-5) anchor:from fontsize:M bar:Aug from:0 till:10 color:cat5red text:"August" bar:Sep from:0 till:19 color:cat5red text:"September" bar:Oct from:0 till:1 color:cat5red text:"October" bar:Nov from:0 till:1 color:cat5red text:"November" ScaleMajor = gridcolor:line unit:year increment:15 start:0 ScaleMinor = gridcolor:minorline unit:year increment:1 start:0 TextData = fontsize:M textcolor:black pos:(100,25) # tabs:(100-left) text:"Number of storms affecting West Africa"
{{Col-end}} ==Deadliest storms== The following is a list of Atlantic tropical storms that caused fatalities in West Africa and its surrounding islands.
{| class="wikitable" align="center" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Name ! Year ! Number of deaths |- | [[Tropical Storm Fran (1984)|Fran]] || 1984 || 31 |- | [[Tropical Storm Delta (2005)|Delta]] || 2005 || 19 |- | [[Hurricane Fred (2015)|Fred]] || 2015 || 9 |- | [[Tropical Storm Beryl (1982)|Beryl]] || 1982 || 3 |- | [[Tropical Storm Helene (2018)|Helene]] || 2018 || 3 |}
==See also== {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} *[[Tropical cyclone]] *[[List of Atlantic hurricanes]] *[[List of notable tropical cyclones]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of West Africa Hurricanes}} [[Category:Lists of tropical cyclones by area|Africa (West)]] [[Category:Tropical cyclones in Africa|*]]

revision.text:
{{external links|date=June 2016}} [[File:Heaquarters bogor.jpg|thumb|[[Center for International Forestry Research|CIFOR]] headquarters, [[Bogor, Indonesia|Bogor]]]]
This is a '''list of forest [[research institute]]s''' around the world, by continent and country. It includes research institutions with a primary focus on [[forest science]], [[forestry]], [[forest management]], and related fields. {{Expand list|date=December 2011}} {{TOC right|limit=3}}
==International== * [[Center for International Forestry Research]] (CIFOR), [[Bogor]], Indonesia * [[Center for Tropical Forest Science]], [[Panama City]], Panama * [[European Forest Institute]], [[Joensuu]], Finland * [[International Union of Forest Research Organizations]] (IUFRO) [[Vienna]], Austria
==Africa==
=== Algeria === * [[:fr:Institut national de recherche forestière|Institut national de recherche forestière (INRF)]] ''{{fr}}'' === Ethiopia === * [[Ethiopian Environment and Forest Research Institute]] === Ghana === * [[Forestry Research Institute of Ghana]]
=== Kenya === * [[Kenya Forestry Research Institute]]
=== Malawi === * [[Forestry Research Institute of Malawi]]
=== Nigeria === * [[Forestry Research Institute of Nigeria]]
===South Africa=== * [[Council for Scientific and Industrial Research]] * [[Institute for Commercial Forestry Research]] * [[Forestry and Agricultural Biotechnology Institute]] (FABI), [[University of Pretoria]] * [[Forestry and Forest Products Research Center]], [[Durban]], "a joint venture between [[Council for Scientific and Industrial Research|CSIR]]'s Natural Resources and the Environment operating unit and the [[University of KwaZulu-Natal]]"<ref>[http://ffp.csir.co.za/ Official website.] Accessed: September 28, 2012.</ref> * [[Merensky (wood products firm)|Merensky]]<ref>[http://forestry.daff.gov.za/webapp/ResearchDevelopment.aspx Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries]. Accessed: March 11, 2012.</ref>
=== Uganda === * [[Institute of Tropical Forest Conservation]]
== Americas ==
=== Canada === [[File:Beech Leaf - Edward George Falkenberg.jpg|thumb|Ontario Forest Research Institute]] * Atlantic Forestry Centre<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/forests/research-centres/afc/13447|title=Atlantic Forestry Centre|publisher=}}</ref> * Canadian Wood Fibre Centre<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/forests/research-centres/cwfc/13457|title=Canadian Wood Fibre Centre|publisher=}}</ref> * Great Lakes Forestry Centre, Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/forests/research-centres/glfc/13459|title=Great Lakes Forestry Centre|publisher=}}</ref> * Laurentian Forestry Centre<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/forests/research-centres/lfc/13473|title=Laurentian Forestry Centre|publisher=}}</ref> * Northern Forestry Centre<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/forests/research-centres/nofc/13485|title=Northern Forestry Centre|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Ontario Forest Research Institute]] * Pacific Forestry Centre<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/forests/research-centres/pfc/13489|title=Pacific Forestry Centre|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Chile === * [[El Instituto Forestal]]
=== Puerto Rico === * [[International Institute of Tropical Forestry]]
=== Suriname === * [[Centre for Agricultural Research in Suriname]]
===United States=== * [[Forest Products Laboratory]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fpl.fs.fed.us/|title=USDA Forest Service - Forest Products Laboratory|publisher=}}</ref> * Institute for Resource Information Systems<ref>[http://www.irisinfosys.org I.R.I.S.® - Institute for Resource Information Systems (TM/SM).] Accessed February 12, 2015.</ref> * International Institute of Tropical Forestry<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/iitf|title=IITF - Home|publisher=}}</ref> * Northern Research Station<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrs.fs.fed.us/|title=Northern Research Station|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Oregon Forest Resources Institute]] * Pacific Northwest Research Station<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/pnw/|title=Pacific Northwest Research Station|publisher=}}</ref> * Pacific Southwest Research Station<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/psw/|title=Pacific Southwest Research Station|publisher=}}</ref> * Rocky Mountain Research Station<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/rmrs/|title=Rocky Mountain Research Station - RMRS - US Forest Service|publisher=}}</ref> * Southern Research Station<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.srs.fs.usda.gov/index.php|title=USDA Forest Service Southern Research Station|publisher=}}</ref> * [[United States Forest Service#Research and development|USDA Forest Service, Research and Development Branch]]
==Asia==
=== Bangladesh === * [[Bangladesh Forest Research Institute]] (formerly, Forest Products Research Laboratory)
===India=== [[File:Forest Research Institute, Dehradun, India.jpg|thumb|Forest Research Institute, Dehadrun]] {{Main article|List of forest research institutes in India}}
* [[Advanced Research Centre for Bamboo and Rattan]], Aizawl * [[Arid Forest Research Institute]], Jodhpur * [[Centre for Forest Based Livelihood and Extension]], Agarlata * [[Centre for Forestry Research and Human Resource Development]], Chhindwara * [[Centre for Social Forestry and Eco-Rehabilitation]], Allahabad * Forest College and Research Institute, [[Tamil Nadu Agricultural University]], [[Mettupalayam, Coimbatore|Mettupalayam]]<ref>[http://www.tnau.ac.in/fcri/About.html "Forest College and Research Institute", Tamil Nadu Agricultural University.] Accessed: November 7, 2012.</ref> * [[Forest Research Institute (India)|Forest Research Institute]], Dehradun * Forest Research Institute, Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh Forest Department * Gujarat Forest Research Institute * [[Himalayan Forest Research Institute]], Shimla * [[Institute of Forest Biodiversity]], Hyderabad * [[Institute of Forest Genetics and Tree Breeding]], Coimbatore * [[Institute of Forest Productivity]], Ranchi * [[Institute of Wood Science and Technology]], Banglore * [[Kerala Forest Research Institute]], [[Peechi]], [[Thrissur]] * [[Rain Forest Research Institute]], Jorhat * [[Tropical Forest Research Institute]], Jabalpur * [[Van Vigyan Kendra]] (Forest Science Centres)
=== Japan === * [[Yamanashi Forest Research Institute]]
=== Korea === * [[National Institute of Forest Science]]
=== Lao P.D.R. === * [[National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute]]
=== Malaysia === * [[Forest Research Institute Malaysia]] * [[Malaysia Palm Oil Board]]
=== Myanmar (Burma) === * [[Forest Research Institute (Myanmar)|Forest Research Institute]], affiliated with the [[University of Forestry (Yezin)]]
=== Pakistan === * [[Pakistan Forest Institute, Peshawar]]
=== Taiwan === * [[Taiwan Forestry Research Institute]]
=== Tajikistan === * [[Tajik State Forest Research Institute]], [[Dushanbe]], affiliated with the [[Forestry Agency (Tajikistan)|Forestry Agency]] under the [[Government of Tajikistan]]
===Thailand=== * [[Forest Restoration Research Unit]], Chiang Mai
=== Vietnam === * [[Forestry Science Institute of Vietnam]]
==Europe== [[File:Metla research forest.jpg|thumb|right|Metla research forest]]
=== Austria === * [[Federal Forest Research Centre Vienna]]<ref>[http://bfw.ac.at/db/bfwcms.web?dok=4684 BFW, "History"] Accessed: May 7, 2012.</ref>
=== Belgium === * [[Research Institute for Nature and Forest]]
=== Finland === * [[Finnish Forest Research Institute]] (Metla)
=== Germany ===
* Bayerische Landesanstalt für Wald und Forstwirtschaft<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lwf.bayern.de/|title=Bayerische Landesanstalt für Wald und Forstwirtschaft|publisher=}}</ref> * Forschungsanstalt für Waldökologie und Forstwirtschaft Rheinland-Pfalz<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fawf.wald-rlp.de/|title=Landesforsten Rheinland-Pfalz: Forschungsanstalt für Waldökologie und Forstwirtschaft|author=|date=|website=www.fawf.wald-rlp.de}}</ref> * Forstliche Versuchs- und Forschungsanstalt Baden-Württemberg<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fva-bw.de/|title=Forstliche Versuchs- und Forschungsanstalt BW|publisher=}}</ref> * Landesbetrieb Wald und Holz NRW - Lehr- und Versuchsforstamt Arnsberger Wald<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wald-und-holz.nrw.de/ueber-uns/einrichtungen/lehr-und-versuchsforstamt-arnsberger-wald/|title=Lehr- und Versuchsforstamt Arnsberger Wald - Wald & Holz|date=4 April 2016|publisher=}}</ref> * Landesforst Mecklenburg-Vorpommern - Forstliches Versuchswesen<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wald-mv.de/forstliches_versuchswesen-1562-21-1-12-25.html|title=Landesforst M-V - Forstliches Versuchswesen|publisher=}}</ref> * Landeskompetenzzentrum Forst Eberswalde (Brandenburg)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forst.brandenburg.de/sixcms/detail.php/474880|title=Landeskompetenzzentrum Forst Eberswalde (LFE)|publisher=}}</ref> * Nordwestdeutsche Forstliche Versuchsanstalt (Niedersachsen, Hessen, Sachsen-Anhalt, Schleswig-Holstein)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nw-fva.de/|title=Aktuelles|publisher=nw-fva.de}}</ref> * Sachsenforst - Kompetenzzentrum Wald und Forstwirtschaft<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smul.sachsen.de/sbs/16978.htm|title=Kompetenzzentrum Wald und Forstwirtschaft|author=Gerstenberger, Andy|publisher=}}</ref> * Thünen-Institut - Institut für Waldökosysteme<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vti.bund.de/de/wo/|title=Thünen-Institut: Waldökosysteme|publisher=}}</ref> * Thüringenforst - Forstliches Forschungs- und Kompetenzzentrum Gotha<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thueringenforst.de/ueber-thueringenforst/forstliches-forschungs-und-kompetenzzentrum/uebersicht/|title=Forstliches Forschungs- und Kompetenzzentrum Gotha - Thüringen Forst|date=15 March 2016|work=Thüringen Forst}}</ref>
=== Latvia === * Latvian State Forest Research Institute "Silava" <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.silava.lv/mainen/about-us.aspx|title=Silava - About us|author=|date=|website=www.silava.lv}}</ref>
=== Norway === * [[Norwegian Forest Research Institute]] * Norwegian Institute of Bioeconomy Research<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nibio.no/en|title=Nibio EN - Nibio|author=|date=|website=www.nibio.no}}</ref>
=== Russia === * [[Forestry Engineering Academy]], [[Saint Petersburg]]<ref>[http://www.encspb.ru/object/2804011999?lc=en St. Petersburg Encyclopedia.] Accessed: May 6, 2012.</ref> * [[Saint Petersburg Forestry Research Institute]], since 1929, Saint Petersburg<ref>[http://spb-niilh.ru/en/ Official website]. Accessed September 28, 2012.</ref> * [[Sukachev Institute of Forest]], [[Russian Academy of Sciences]], Moscow
=== Spain === * [[Forest Sciences Centre of Catalonia]] (CTFC)<ref>http://www.ctfc.cat</ref>
=== Sweden === * [[Forestry Research Institute of Sweden]] (Skogforsk)
=== United Kingdom === * [[Forestry Commission#Forest Research|Forest Research]] (agency), Forestry Commission ** Aberystwyth Research Unit<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/fr/INFD-7XQF5B|title=Contact us - Forest Research in Wales (Forest Research)|publisher=}}</ref> ** Alice Holt Research Station<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/fr/INFD-5UWHXL|title=Alice Holt Research Station|publisher=}}</ref> ** Northern Research Station <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/fr/INFD-5UWJHD|title=Northern Research Station|publisher=}}</ref>
==Oceania==

List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2012

revision.comment: Rescuing 5 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}}
{{Use American English|date=May 2016}} The following is a '''list of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2012'''. It is one of several [[list of pipeline accidents in the United States|lists of U.S. pipeline accidents]]. See also [[list of natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States]]. {{expand list|date=April 2013}} __NOTOC__ <!--begin temporary compact toc--> <!-- something nicer-looking and more navigable should be done here; this is a temporary TOC to ease navigation --> <!-- | bgcolor=#dddddd align=center colspan=11 | See also – [[#References|References]] --> <!--end compact toc-->
== Incidents ==
This is not a complete list of all pipeline accidents. '''For natural gas alone''', the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), a United States Department of Transportation agency, has collected data on more than 3,200 accidents deemed serious or significant since 1987.
A "significant incident" results in any of the following consequences: * fatality or injury requiring in-patient hospitalization * $50,000 or more in total costs, measured in 1984 dollars * liquid releases of five or more barrels (42 US gal/barrel) * releases resulting in an unintentional fire or explosion
PHMSA and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) post incident data and results of investigations into accidents involving pipelines that carry a variety of products, including natural gas, oil, diesel fuel, gasoline, kerosene, jet fuel, carbon dioxide, and other substances. Occasionally pipelines are repurposed to carry different products.<ref>Data sets of PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 1986-2001, 2002-2009, and 2010-2017 can be downloaded from the tab by that name on the PHMSA's Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10. PHMSA Corrective Action Orders are at https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/CAO_opid_0.html. PHMSA Pipeline Failure Investigation Reports are at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/safety-reports/pipeline-failure-investigation-reports. NTSB Pipeline Accident Reports are at https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/pipeline.aspx.</ref>
* A 30-inch gas pipeline exploded and burned, in [[Estill County, Kentucky]], on the evening of January 2. The rupture created a crater approximately 86 feet long by 22 feet wide, and expelled a number of pieces of pipe as far as 800 feet from the rupture center. Flames were reported reaching over 1,000 feet high. Residents up to a mile away from the failure were evacuated. There were no injuries. The cause was overstress from land movement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyt.com/wymtnews/headlines/136548983.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106210254/http://www.wkyt.com/wymtnews/headlines/136548983.html |archivedate=January 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Failure Investigation Report – Columbia Gulf Transmission, Line 200 Rupture in Estill County, Kentucky Failure Date – January 2, 2012 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/CGT_Estill_Co_KY_[Redacted_for_Internet].pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131220027/http://phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/CGT_Estill_Co_KY_%5BRedacted_for_Internet%5D.pdf# |archivedate=January 31, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * A forest fire caused a gas pipeline to explode and burn in [[Floyd County, Kentucky]] on January 7. There were no injuries from this incident.<ref>[http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/4d82f196216f484dacfd7657510abcaa/KY--Explosion-Fire/]{{dead link|date=May 2016}}</ref> * On January 9, a man was killed, and another person injured, in a fiery house explosion from a leaking 4-inch cast iron gas main installed in 1950 in [[Austin, Texas]]. Gas had been smelled in the area for several weeks prior to this. Gas company crews had looked along the affected property for a leak, but were unable to find it.<ref name="opsweb.phmsa.dot.gov">{{cite web |url=http://opsweb.phmsa.dot.gov/cast_iron/ |title=Page has moved |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150310100120/http://opsweb.phmsa.dot.gov/cast_iron/# |archivedate=March 10, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/local/man-feared-dead-in-home-explosion-had-hoped-2094583.html |title=Man feared dead in home explosion had hoped to move near son |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120129091720/http://www.statesman.com/news/local/man-feared-dead-in-home-explosion-had-hoped-2094583.html |archivedate=January 29, 2012 }}</ref> * A [[Sunoco]] pipeline ruptured and spilled about 117,000 gallons of gasoline, in [[Wellington, Ohio]], late on January 12. Some residents were evacuated for a week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/state/article/224794/23/Wellington-Families-still-evacuated-after-massive-pipeline-spill|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120919182535/http://www.wkyc.com/news/state/article/224794/23/Wellington-Families-still-evacuated-after-massive-pipeline-spill|dead-url=yes|archive-date=September 19, 2012|title=Wellington: Families still evacuated after massive pipeline spill|author=|date=January 13, 2012|publisher=|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/oh_lorain/wellington-may-have-answers-in-the-coming-weeks |title=Wellington may have answers in the coming weeks |work=newsnet5 |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027232258/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/oh_lorain/wellington-may-have-answers-in-the-coming-weeks |archivedate=October 27, 2013}}</ref> * On January 13, an 8-inch gas pipeline exploded and burned, in a vacant agricultural field, in [[Rio Vista, California]]. There were no injuries or evacuations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_19739515 |title=No injuries, damage after gas line explodes in Rio Vista |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714124305/http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_19739515 |archivedate=July 14, 2014 }}</ref> * A [[Tennessee Gas Pipeline]] gas compressor had a major leak "that sounded like a rocket" in [[Powell County, Kentucky]], forcing evacuations of nearby residents on January 14. There was no fire or injuries reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lex18.com/news/gas-leak-in-powell-county |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119085823/http://www.lex18.com/news/gas-leak-in-powell-county |archivedate=January 19, 2012}}</ref> * A contractor excavating for a communications company caused a massive gas explosion and fire at a condominium complex on January 16 in [[West Haverstraw, New York]], injuring two firefighters and two utility workers. Afterwards, it was found that the excavator's insurance will be insufficient to cover all of the property damage of the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lohud.com/article/20120121/NEWS03/301200069/Cortlandt-contractor-gas-explosion-may-lack-enough-insurance-lawyer-homeowners-says |title=Cortlandt contractor in gas explosion may lack enough insurance, lawyer for homeowners says |work=The Journal News – lohud.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223060211/http://www.lohud.com/article/20120121/NEWS03/301200069/Cortlandt-contractor-gas-explosion-may-lack-enough-insurance-lawyer-homeowners-says |archivedate=February 23, 2015}}</ref> * On January 18, the original [[Colonial Pipeline]] mainline failed in [[Belton, South Carolina]], spilling about 13,500 gallons of petroleum product. The failure was caused by internal corrosion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/273705 |title=Jan. 18, 2012 – ProPublica |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714145123/http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/273705 |archivedate=July 14, 2014 }}</ref> * Workers in [[Topeka, Kansas]] were installing a yard sprinkler system on January 30 when they hit a gas line. Gas from the leak later on exploded in a nearby house, burning a 73-year-old woman, who died several weeks later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wibw.com/home/headlines/Building_Explosion_138335069.html |title=Details About Victim Of Home Explosion Released |author1=Giang Nguyen |author2=Marques White |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020085806/http://www.wibw.com/home/headlines/Building_Explosion_138335069.html |archivedate=October 20, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wibw.com/community/headlines//Home_explosion_Victim_Dies_138718084.html |title=Home Explosion Victim Dies |author=Stephanie Ramos-Tomeoni |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020085804/http://www.wibw.com/community/headlines//Home_explosion_Victim_Dies_138718084.html |archivedate=October 20, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * On January 31, a [[Shell Oil Company]] fuel pipeline to the [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]] Mitchell International Airport was found to be leaking. Jet fuel had been smelled for about two weeks in the area, and was found in runoff water in the area. The cause was from external corrosion. About 9,000 gallons of fuel were spilled. In 2014, a Shell employee was scheduled to plead guilty to charges of falsifying records of the pipeline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wisn.com/news/30345282/detail.html|title=Jet Fuel Leaks For 2 Weeks Into Sewer|work=WISN|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/milwaukee/ex-shell-pipeline-monitor-to-plead-guilty-in-airport-leak-b99392450z1-282987621.html |title=Former Shell Pipeline monitor to plead guilty in airport leak |author=Bruce Vielmetti |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121055823/http://www.jsonline.com/news/milwaukee/ex-shell-pipeline-monitor-to-plead-guilty-in-airport-leak-b99392450z1-282987621.html |archivedate=January 21, 2015 }}</ref> * On February 13, a Florida Gas Transmission Company 30-inch gas transmission pipeline burst near [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]]. Residents in the area were evacuated for a time, but there was no fire. The pipe, manufactured in 1965, ruptured due to external corrosion. DOT/PHMSA assessed a fine of $197,200 against FGT for 2 violations of safety regulations on corrosion control and issued a corrective order.<ref>PHMSA Federal Enforcement Case CPF 4-2013-1019.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 4-2013-1014H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420131014H/420131014H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_06242013.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211183434/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/Comm/Reports/enforce/documents/420131014H/420131014H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_06242013.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31174.html?nocache=2826#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications |website=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126141644/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31174.html?nocache=2826 |archivedate=January 26, 2016 }}</ref> * On February 15, 2012, in [[Arenac County, Michigan]], oil was discovered in the soil around a 30-inch [[Enbridge]] crude oil pipeline. About 800 gallons of crude oil were spilled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_11169.html?nocache=3470#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications |website=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129063140/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_11169.html?nocache=3470 |archivedate=November 29, 2014 }}</ref> * Two cars that were drag racing went off the road and crashed through a fence and into a crude oil pipeline in [[New Lenox, Illinois]] on March 3. The pipeline was ruptured, and the crude oil ignited. Two men from the vehicles were killed, and three others seriously burned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firerescue1.com/fire-attack/articles/1247826-2-killed-by-Ill-oil-pipeline-explosion/ |title=2 killed by Ill. oil pipeline explosion |work=FireRescue1.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141102095710/http://www.firerescue1.com/fire-attack/articles/1247826-2-killed-by-Ill-oil-pipeline-explosion/ |archivedate=November 2, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFL2E8E7FYA20120307?sp=true |agency=Reuters |title=Late-night car race that caused pipeline fire rare, not unique |date=March 7, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022072101/https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFL2E8E7FYA20120307?sp=true |archivedate=October 22, 2014 }}</ref> * On March 5, a leak at an [[Enid, Oklahoma]] pipeline storage facility spread propane fumes in the area, forcing evacuations. There was no fire or explosion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/business/article.aspx?subjectid=49&articleid=20120306_49_0_ENIDCr320893|title=Tulsa World|first1=Tulsa World: Tulsa|last1=news|first2=|last2=sports|first3=|last3=business|first4=|last4=entertainment|first5=|last5=weather|work=tulsaworld.com|accessdate=September 16, 2016}}</ref> * A crude oil pipeline leaked near [[Grand Isle, Louisiana]] on March 17, spilling as much as 8,400 gallons of crude oil. There were no injuries reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/environment/index.ssf/2012/03/officials_finish_cleaning_crud.html |title=Officials finish cleaning crude from leaky pipeline in Barataria Bay |work=NOLA.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022105725/http://www.nola.com/environment/index.ssf/2012/03/officials_finish_cleaning_crud.html |archivedate=October 22, 2014 }}</ref> * On March 29, an employee accidentally left a valve open during maintenance work on a [[Williams Companies]] gas compressor station near [[Springville Township, Pennsylvania]]. Later, gas leaked through the valve, causing alarms to evacuate workers in the compressor building. Later, the gas exploded and burned. There were no injuries. It was also found there are no agencies enforcing rules on rural gas facilities in that state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/20120408_Northern_Pennsylvania_gas_explosion_was_out_of_regulatory_reach.html?viewAll=y|title=Northern Pennsylvania gas explosion was out of regulatory reach|work=Philly.com|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thetimes-tribune.com/news/explosion-at-natural-gas-compressor-station-1.1292502#axzz1qWyVU1UF|title=Explosion rocks natural gas compressor station|author=Laura Legere|publisher=|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref> * On April 2, Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Company, reported a leak on their 72nd Street Interstate Transmission Lateral located in [[North Bergen, New Jersey]]. Workers discovered a rock in contact with the bottom of the pipe. Upon removing the rock, the pipeline began to leak. There was no fire or injuries reported as a result of this incident.<ref>{{cite web |title=Williams Gas Pipeline-Transco; North Bergen, NJ, 72nd Street Interstate Trans Lateral Leak Failure Date: 4/2/2012 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/139107_Williams_Gas_Pipeline_North_Bergen_NJ_2012[Redacted_for_Internet].pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170210152455/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/139107_Williams_Gas_Pipeline_North_Bergen_NJ_2012%5BRedacted_for_Internet%5D.pdf# |archivedate=February 10, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * A 12-inch gas pipeline exploded and burned for five hours near [[Gary, Texas]] on April 4. There were no injuries, but the rupture site was only 200 feet from that pipeline's compressor station.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kcentv.com/story/17337012/pipeline-explodes-near-carthage |title=Pipeline explodes near Carthage |author=Amy Tatum |date=April 4, 2012 |work=kcentv.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.kcentv.com/story/17337012/pipeline-explodes-near-carthage |archivedate=February 3, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * On April 6, two gas company workers were mildly burned when attempting to fix a leak on a 4-inch gas pipeline in [[DeSoto County, Mississippi]]. The pipeline exploded and burned during the repairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2012/apr/07/in-brief/ |title=In brief: Repairs continue on leaking line |work=MCA |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028000524/http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2012/apr/07/in-brief/ |archivedate=October 28, 2013}}</ref> * On April 9, a [[Texas Gas Transmission]] 16-inch diameter natural gas pipeline exploded and burned in [[Terrebonne Parish, Louisiana]]. The pipe, manufactured in 1961, failed due to corrosion.<ref>PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents (2010-2017), link on the Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at www.phmsa.dot.govdata-and-statisticspipelinepipeline-incident-flagged-files.</ref> The accident was reported first by a satellite monitoring the area to the NRC. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/business/index.ssf/2012/04/natural_gas_pipeline_ruptures.html |title=Natural gas pipeline ruptures, sending flames soaring in Terrebonne Parish marshes |work=NOLA.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022105637/http://www.nola.com/business/index.ssf/2012/04/natural_gas_pipeline_ruptures.html |archivedate=October 22, 2014 }}</ref> * Two men escaped with only minor burns after a bulldozer they were using hit a 24-inch gas pipeline near [[Hinton, Iowa]] on April 25. Authorities later announced the men did not call 811 for an underground utility locate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ktiv.com/story/17797831/northern-natural-gas-men-did-not-check-for-line |title=Northern Natural Gas: Men did not check for pipeline |date=April 26, 2012 |work=ktiv.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.ktiv.com/story/17797831/northern-natural-gas-men-did-not-check-for-line |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On April 28, an [[ExxonMobil]] 20/22-inch-diameter pipeline ruptured near [[Torbert, Louisiana|Torbert]] in [[Pointe Coupee Parish, Louisiana]], about 20 miles west of Baton Rouge, and crude oil spilled into the surrounding area, and flowed into an unnamed tributary connected to Bayou Cholpe. About 117,000 gallons of crude were spilled, with about 37,000 gallons being lost. The pipeline failed due to a manufacturing defect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_4906.html?nocache=4538#_Incidents_tab_4 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications |website=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022132728/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_4906.html?nocache=4538 |archivedate=October 22, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 4-2012-5019H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420125019H/420125019H_CAO_05082012.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211092454/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/Comm/Reports/enforce/documents/420125019H/420125019H_CAO_05082012.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wateronline.com/doc/exxonmobil-pipeline-company-resolves-clean-water-act-violation-stemming-spill-0001 |title=ExxonMobil Pipeline Company To Pay Civil Penalty Under Proposed Settlement For Torbert Louisiana Oil Spill Settlement Resolves Clean Water Act Violation Stemming From 2012 Spill |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020124747/http://www.wateronline.com/doc/exxonmobil-pipeline-company-resolves-clean-water-act-violation-stemming-spill-0001 |archivedate=October 20, 2014 }}</ref> * A 26-inch gas transmission pipeline ruptured on June 6 in a compressor station near [[Laketon, Texas|Laketon]] in northeastern [[Gray County, Texas]]. Gas escaped from the 50-foot-long rupture, igniting, leaving a crater 30 feet in diameter, burning two acres of agricultural area and telephone poles. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 4-2012-1011H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420121011H/420121011H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_06122012.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211183721/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/Comm/reports/enforce/documents/420121011H/420121011H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_06122012.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref> * On June 8, near [[Canadian, Texas]], a trackhoe operator suffered burns, after a fire from leaking 4-inch gas-gathering pipeline that was undergoing maintenance. Fumes entered the engine of the trackhoe and ignited.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kristv.com/news/pipeline-worker-hurt-in-texas-panhandle-explosion/|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130127051818/http://www.kristv.com/news/pipeline-worker-hurt-in-texas-panhandle-explosion/|deadurl=yes|title=Pipeline Worker Hurt in Texas Panhandle Explosion - Corpus Christi, T…|date=January 27, 2013|archivedate=January 27, 2013|publisher=}}</ref> * A contractor was killed and two others injured after an explosion at a [[BP]] gas compressor station in [[Durango, Colorado]] on June 25. [[BP]], [[Halliburton]], and the other contractors were fined $7,000 each for safety violations in that work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hazardexonthenet.net/article/51303/BP-gas-compressor-station-explosion-in-Colorado-kills-one.aspx |title=HazardEx – BP gas compressor station explosion in Colorado kills one |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108231846/http://www.hazardexonthenet.net/article/51303/BP-gas-compressor-station-explosion-in-Colorado-kills-one.aspx |archivedate=November 8, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.krqe.com/dpp/news/colorado/ap_colorado/BP-Halliburton-fined-in-fatal-pipeline-explosion_54659132 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=January 24, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130201232344/http://www.krqe.com/dpp/news/colorado/ap_colorado/BP-Halliburton-fined-in-fatal-pipeline-explosion_54659132 |archivedate=February 1, 2013}}</ref> * A West Shore Pipe Line petroleum products pipeline burst near [[Jackson, Washington County, Wisconsin|Jackson, Wisconsin]] on July 17, releasing about 54,000 gallons of gasoline. At least one family self evacuated due to the leak. At least 44 water wells nearby were contaminated from benzine in the gasoline, including a municipal well. A LF-[[Electric resistance welding|ERW]] seam failure was suspected as the cause. Further testing revealed that at least 26 other areas on this pipeline needed repairs, with 22 within the Jackson Marsh Wildlife Area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/ozwash/tests-reveal-chemicals-in-23-more-jackson-wells-b9946404z1-214289551.html |title=Tests reveal chemicals in 23 more Jackson wells |author=Don Behm |archivedate=October 22, 2014 }}</ref> * A 14-inch gas gathering pipeline exploded and burned on July 18 near [[Intracoastal City, Louisiana]]. There were no injuries or major property damage reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eunicetoday.com/view/full_story/19367444/article-Gas-line-blows-in-Intracoastal-City--no-one-hurt?instance%3Dsecondary_news_left_column |title=Archived copy |accessdate=July 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120815051857/http://www.eunicetoday.com/view/full_story/19367444/article-Gas-line-blows-in-Intracoastal-City--no-one-hurt?instance=secondary_news_left_column |archivedate=August 15, 2012}}</ref> * On July 23, a compressor station operated by [[Williams Companies]] in [[Windsor, New York]] was venting gas in a "routine procedure" — during a lightning storm — when the vent was ignited by lightning, causing a fireball "hundreds of feet into the air"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.naturalgaswatch.org/?p=1459 |title=This Week In Natural Gas Leaks and Explosions – July 30, 2012 – Natural Gas Watch.org |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150620021255/http://www.naturalgaswatch.org/?p=1459# |archivedate=June 20, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wbng.com/news/local/Lightning-Causes-Compressor-Explosion-163497506.html |title=Lightning Causes Compressor Explosion |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227105411/http://www.wbng.com/news/local/Lightning-Causes-Compressor-Explosion-163497506.html |archivedate=December 27, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * An [[Enbridge]] crude oil pipeline ruptured in [[Grand Marsh, Wisconsin]], releasing an estimated 1,200 barrels of crude oil. The pipeline had been installed in 1998. Flaws in the longitudinal welds had been seen during X-ray checks of girth welds.<ref name="phmsa.dot.gov">{{cite web |title=CPF No. 3-2012-5017H |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Corrective_Action_Order_073012.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130222200918/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Corrective_Action_Order_073012.pdf# |archivedate=February 22, 2013 |access-date=October 2, 2018 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/29/enbridge-pipeline-idUSL2E8IT1AL20120729 |agency=Reuters |title=UPDATE 4-Enbridge to replace leaky Wisconsin oil pipeline Monday |date=July 29, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730091407/https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/29/enbridge-pipeline-idUSL2E8IT1AL20120729 |archivedate=July 30, 2012 }}</ref> * Four contract workers were injured during a flash fire at a [[Wyoming]] gas processing plant on August 22.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://trib.com/business/energy/burned-in-lost-cabin-gas-plant-explosion/article_3f7c4b8a-f89a-5de1-9afe-ea88e8bf25f9.html |title=Four burned in Lost Cabin gas plant flash fire |author=Jeremy Fugleberg |work=Casper Star-Tribune Online |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030165409/http://trib.com/business/energy/burned-in-lost-cabin-gas-plant-explosion/article_3f7c4b8a-f89a-5de1-9afe-ea88e8bf25f9.html |archivedate=October 30, 2012 }}</ref> * A jet fuel pipeline near [[Chicago]] began leaking on August 27. The burst pipeline spilled an estimated 42,000 gallons of jet fuel into a ditch that empties into the Calumet Sag Channel in Palos Heights, Illinois. External corrosion was the cause of the pipeline failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ens-newswire.com/2012/08/28/jet-fuel-spill-near-chicago-closes-canal-highway/ |title=Jet Fuel Spill Near Chicago Closes Canal, Highway |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140708231445/http://ens-newswire.com/2012/08/28/jet-fuel-spill-near-chicago-closes-canal-highway/ |archivedate=July 8, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 3-2012-5019H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320125019H/320125019H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_08302012.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211183702/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/Comm/reports/enforce/documents/320125019H/320125019H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_08302012.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://palos.patch.com/groups/politics-and-elections/p/pipeline-in-palos-park-was-corroded-company-rep |title=Pipeline in Palos Park Was Corroded: Company Rep |work=Palos, Illinois Patch |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028074633/http://palos.patch.com/groups/politics-and-elections/p/pipeline-in-palos-park-was-corroded-company-rep |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref> * On August 28, a Atmos Energy repair crew struck an 8-inch gas main in [[McKinney, Texas]], causing a fire. Four Atmos workers were treated for injuries. 1,000 Atmos gas customers lost gas service for a time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/national-international/Gas-Line-Explodes-in-McKinney-167677095.html |title=Gas Line Fire Snuffed Out |work=NBC 10 Philadelphia |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218171542/http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/national-international/Gas-Line-Explodes-in-McKinney-167677095.html |archivedate=December 18, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thescoopblog.dallasnews.com/2012/08/gas-line-explodes-in-mckinney.html/ |title=Gas line explosion in McKinney leaves four injured, 1,000 without gas |work=The Scoop Blog |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021012237/http://thescoopblog.dallasnews.com/2012/08/gas-line-explodes-in-mckinney.html/ |archivedate=October 21, 2014 }}</ref> * On September 6, a 10-inch gas gathering pipeline exploded and burned near [[Alice, Texas]]. Flames reached 100 feet high, and caused a 10-acre brush fire. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article1265011.ece |title=Production impact 'minimal' from pipe blast |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article1265011.ece |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * An explosion and fire hit a Crestwood Midstream Partners gas compressor station in [[Hood County, Texas]] on September 6. Heavy damage to a sheet metal building resulted, but there were no injuries reported to crew there.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hcnews.com/pages/updates/cause-of-sept-6-explosion-at-gas-plant-still-being-investigated/ |title=Cause of Sept. 6 explosion at gas plant still being investigated |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028030618/http://hcnews.com/pages/updates/cause-of-sept-6-explosion-at-gas-plant-still-being-investigated/ |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref> * A Colorado Interstate Gas gas compressor in [[Rio Blanco County, Colorado]] caught fire on September 11. There were no reported injuries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/09/12/kindermorgan-cig-fire-idINL1E8KC7PZ20120912 |agency=Reuters |title=Colorado Interstate Gas sets force majeure after compressor fire |date=September 12, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120919025930/http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/09/12/kindermorgan-cig-fire-idINL1E8KC7PZ20120912 |archivedate=September 19, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colorado.gov/cs/Satellite?blobcol%3Durldata%26blobheadername1%3DContent-Disposition%26blobheadername2%3DContent-Type%26blobheadervalue1%3Dinline%3B+filename%3D%22Revised+Technical+Review+Document+%28April+20%2C+2012%29.pdf%22%26blobheadervalue2%3Dapplication%2Fpdf%26blobkey%3Did%26blobtable%3DMungoBlobs%26blobwhere%3D1251808828542%26ssbinary%3Dtrue |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130408133106/http://www.colorado.gov/cs/Satellite?blobcol=urldata&blobheadername1=Content-Disposition&blobheadername2=Content-Type&blobheadervalue1=inline%3B+filename%3D%22Revised+Technical+Review+Document+%28April+20%2C+2012%29.pdf%22&blobheadervalue2=application%2Fpdf&blobkey=id&blobtable=MungoBlobs&blobwhere=1251808828542&ssbinary=true |archivedate=April 8, 2013 |df= }}</ref> * On September 24, an excavator struck a 4-inch natural gas line on Route 416 in [[Montgomery (town), New York|Montgomery, New York]]. Escaping gas ignited, and it took 90 minutes before the gas was shut off. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20120924%2FNEWS%2F120929866 |title=Natural gas line struck by excavator near Orange County Airport |work=recordonline.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141025214646/http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20120924%2FNEWS%2F120929866 |archivedate=October 25, 2014 }}</ref> * On October 3, a [[Colonial Pipeline]] stubline leaked gasoline into in a marshy area of [[Moccasin Bend]], about 1,000 feet from the [[Tennessee River]], near [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]]. About 3,600 gallons of gasoline were spilled, with about 1000 gallons being lost. The cause was from previous excavation damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/local/story/2012/oct/05/gasoline-spill-on-moccasin-bend-under-review/89679/ |title=Gasoline spill on Moccasin Bend under review |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109113456/http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/local/story/2012/oct/05/gasoline-spill-on-moccasin-bend-under-review/89679/ |archivedate=January 9, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_2552.html?nocache=6255#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Operator Information |website=primis.phmsa.dot.gov |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109114420/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_2552.html?nocache=6255 |archivedate=January 9, 2017 }}</ref> * The operator of an excavator machine narrowly escaped serious injury in [[Lewiston, Idaho]] on November 19, when his machine hit a gas pipeline during road work. The resulting fire destroyed a railroad signal, along with several telephone poles, and road construction equipment. The depth of the pipeline has been misjudged at that location.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idahopress.com/news/state/gas-explosion-lights-the-sky-in-downtown-lewiston/article_64ad1772-32d5-11e2-9ddc-0019bb2963f4.html |title=Gas explosion lights the sky in downtown Lewiston |work=Idaho Press-Tribune |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222123936/http://www.idahopress.com/news/state/gas-explosion-lights-the-sky-in-downtown-lewiston/article_64ad1772-32d5-11e2-9ddc-0019bb2963f4.html web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-11-21/bp-chicap-pipe-spilled-oil-at-illinois-tank-farm-filing-shows |title=BP Chicap Pipe Spilled Oil at Illinois Tank Farm, Filing Shows |author=Aaron Two men were injured in an explosion and fire at a natural gas production facility east of [[Price, Utah]] on November 20.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsok.com/2-workers-hurt-in-natural-gas-explosion-near-price/article/feed/465555 |title=2 workers hurt in natural gas explosion near Price |work=NewsOK.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021040712/http://newsok.com/2-workers-hurt-in-natural-gas-explosion-near-price/article/feed/465555 |archivedate=October 21, 2014 }}</ref> * On November 23, a gas company worker looking for the source of a reported gas leak in a [[Springfield, Massachusetts]] strip club pierced a gas line. The gas later exploded, injuring 21, devastating the strip club, and damaging numerous nearby buildings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2012/11/claims_for_losses_continue_to.html |title=Claims for losses in Springfield explosion continue to mount |work=masslive.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2012/11/claims_for_losses_continue_to.html |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On November 30, a heavy equipment operator punctured a 12-inch gas transmission pipeline, near the city of [[Madera, California]]. The adjacent highway, along with several rural roads, was shut down for hours, while houses and businesses in the area were evacuated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kfsn/story?id=8904603|title=Hwy 99 reopens after a Madera County gas leak|work=ABC30 Fresno|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref> * A malfunction in a gas compressor caused a fire on December 4, north of [[Fort Worth, Texas]]. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pipeline Safety and Injuries {{!}} Explosion Burn Death Lawyers Hill Law Firm |url=http://www.rhlawgroup.com/blog/pipeline-safety-and-injuries-death/ |accessdate=28 November 2016 |date=22 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128134248/http://www.rhlawgroup.com/blog/pipeline-safety-and-injuries-death/ |archivedate=November 28, 2016 }}</ref> * On December 5, a 16-inch gas pipeline at 500 psi of pressure exploded and burned near a natural gas plant in [[Goldsmith, Texas]]. A fireball 250 feet high was created after the explosion, destroying 12 to 15 utility poles, and caliche and rocks the size of bowling balls damaged a road. There were no injuries reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oaoa.com/news/fire_and_rescue/article_834541cc-3f60-11e2-9c44-001a4bcf6878.html|title=Pipe explodes near Goldsmith plant|work=Odessa American|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref> * On December 11, at approximately 12:40pm, a 20-inch gas pipeline owned by [[NiSource Inc.]], parent of [[Columbia Gas Transmission|Columbia Gas]], exploded along I-77 between [[Sissonville, West Virginia|Sissonville]] and Pocatalico, West Virginia. A piece of the pipe twenty feet long was blown out of the ground and had a longitudinal crack that ran the entire twenty feet. The escaping high-pressure natural gas ignited immediately. An area of fire damage about 820 feet wide extended nearly 1,100 feet along the pipeline right-of-way. Three houses were destroyed by the fire, and several other houses were damaged. There were no fatalities or serious injuries. The asphalt pavement of the northbound and southbound lanes of I-77 was heavily damaged by the intense fire. NTSB determined that the probable cause of the pipeline rupture was (1) external corrosion of the pipe wall due to deteriorated coating and ineffective cathodic protection and (2) the failure to detect the corrosion because the pipeline was not inspected or tested after 1988. Contributing to the poor condition of the corrosion protection systems was the rocky backfill used around the buried pipe.<ref>NTSB Pipeline Accident Reports, Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation Pipeline Rupture, Sissonville, West Virginia, December 11, 2012, https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/pipeline.aspx, accessed 2018.01.09.</ref> Early reports announced the NTSB was investigating as to why alarms in the control room for this pipeline did not sound for this failure.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statejournal.com/story/20328434/explosion-highlights-pipeline-safety |title=WV explosion highlights pipeline safety |date=December 12, 2012 |work=statejournal.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115859/http://www.statejournal.com/story/20328434/explosion-highlights-pipeline-safety |archivedate=February 3, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/11/sissonville-west-virginia-explosion_n_2279577.html?ir=Green |work=Huffington Post |title=PHOTOS: West Virginia Gas Line Explodes, Sends Flames Up To 75 Feet In The Air |date=December 11, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121212045355/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/11/sissonville-west-virginia-explosion_n_2279577.html?ir=Green |archivedate=December 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.register-herald.com/breakingnews/x1332354233/Gas-line-explodes-burns-homes-and-roads-near-Sissonville|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130201135453/http://www.register-herald.com/breakingnews/x1332354233/Gas-line-explodes-burns-homes-and-roads-near-Sissonville|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 1, 2013|title=UPDATED: Gas line explodes, burns homes and roads|work=Beckley Register-Herald|accessdate=January 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.com/News/201212120281|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130121061246/http://www.dailymail.com/News/201212120281|deadurl=yes|title=No alarm in Columbia control room as fire raged  - News - Charleston …|date=January 21, 2013|archivedate=January 21, 2013|publisher=}}</ref> The pipe was manufactured in 1967.<ref>PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents (2010-2017) link on the Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at www.phmsa.dot.govdata-and-statisticspipelinepipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10.</ref> * On December 26, a 20-inch Florida Gas Transmission Company pipeline ruptured near [[Melbourne, Florida]], ejecting a 20-foot section of the pipeline. There was no fire or injuries.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 2-2012-1005H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220121005H/220121005H_CAO_12282012.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215110210/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220121005H/220121005H_CAO_12282012.pdf |archivedate=February 15, 2017 }}</ref>

[[Image:Schlierenfoto Mach 1-2 Pfeilflügel - NASA.jpg|thumb|right|[[Schlieren photography|Schlieren photograph]] of an attached shock on a sharp-nosed supersonic body. The Mach angle is acute, showing that the body exceeds Mach 1. The angle of the Mach wave (~59 degrees) indicates a velocity of about Mach 1.17.]] In [[fluid dynamics]], a '''Mach wave''' is a pressure wave traveling with the [[speed of sound]] caused by a slight change of [[pressure]] added to a [[compressible flow]]. These weak waves can combine in supersonic flow to become a [[shock wave]] if sufficient Mach waves are present at any location. Such a shock wave is called a '''Mach stem''' or '''Mach front'''. Thus, it is possible to have shockless compression or expansion in a supersonic flow by having the production of Mach waves sufficiently spaced (''cf.'' [[Isentropic process|isentropic]] compression in supersonic flows). A Mach wave is the weak limit of an oblique shock wave (a normal shock is the other limit).
== Mach angle == A Mach wave propagates across the flow at the '''Mach angle''' ''μ'', which is the angle formed between the Mach wave wavefront and a vector that points opposite to the vector of motion.<ref>[http://www.grc.nasa.gov/WWW/K-12/airplane/machang.html Mach angle] at NASA.</ref> It is given by
<math>\mu = \arcsin\left(\frac{1}{M}\right),</math>
where ''M'' is the [[Mach number]].
Mach waves can be used in [[Schlieren photography|schlieren]] or shadowgraph observations to determine the local Mach number of the flow. Early observations by [[Ernst Mach]] used grooves in the wall of a duct to produce Mach waves in a duct, which were then photographed by the schlieren method, to obtain data about the flow in nozzles and ducts. Mach angles may also occasionally be visualized out of their condensation in air, for example [[vapor cone]]s around aircraft during [[transonic]] flight.
== See also == * [[Gas dynamics]] * [[Prandtl-Meyer expansion fan]] * [[Shadowgraph|Shadowgraph technique]] * [[Schlieren photography]] * [[Shock wave]]
